A **soldier ant**, a, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is an [insect](/wiki/Insect "Insect") that is a stronger, [poisonous](/wiki/Poison "Poison") cousin of the [giant ant](/wiki/Giant_ant "Giant ant"). Soldier ants are among the most common source of early-game deaths, and as of March 2024 they occupy the #3 position on [NAO](/wiki/NAO "NAO")'s [list of most frequent deaths](https://alt.org/nethack/topdeaths.html).

Soldier ants have a bite attack and a poisonous sting attack, and possess [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance").

A soldier ant [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") is poisonous to eat, but eating a soldier ant corpse or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") has a 1⁄5 chance of conveying poison resistance.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 History](#History)
- [4 Origin](#Origin)
- [5 Variants](#Variants)
  - [5.1 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Generation

Randomly generated soldier ants are always created hostile, and may appear in small [groups](/wiki/Group "Group") of 2-4.

An [anthole](/wiki/Anthole "Anthole") may be populated entirely by soldier ants.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

Hostile soldier ants can be generated by the [summon insects](/wiki/Summon_insects "Summon insects") [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell").[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

Soldier ants appear among the a that are part of the first [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") monster class for [Valkyries](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie") and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters that are randomly generated on the [Valkyrie quest](/wiki/Valkyrie_quest "Valkyrie quest").

## Strategy

As with giant ants, soldier ants are very fast at 18 [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed"), and their poisonous sting makes them even deadlier to the point of possible [instadeath](/wiki/Instadeath "Instadeath"). They also have the same [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") of 3 as a giant ant, making them hard to hit without trained-up or enchanted weapons. Even for characters with poison resistance, their stronger attacks can also chew through poorly-armored characters.

The same techniques for escaping or fighting [giant ant swarms](/wiki/Giant_ant#strategy "Giant ant") can work for soldier ants: avoid being surrounded at all costs, and try to lead them through a nearby [corridor](/wiki/Corridor "Corridor") or close [doors](/wiki/Door "Door") to block them off. Keep an eye on where any [stairs](/wiki/Stairs "Stairs") are located and be prepared to retreat there if possible - avoid being [burdened](/wiki/Burdened "Burdened") if at all reasonable to maximize your movement speed. [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth") reliably works on soldier ants, and any form of magic can work as well since they also have no [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)"). Have whatever [escape items](/wiki/Escape_item "Escape item") you can, e.g. [scrolls](/wiki/Scroll "Scroll") of [teleportation](/wiki/Scroll_of_teleportation "Scroll of teleportation") and wands of [teleportation](/wiki/Wand_of_teleportation "Wand of teleportation"), ready to go if a group of ants threatens to overwhelm you, and once you escape them steer clear as long as possible until you can deal with them.

For characters capable of fighting soldier ant swarms, use your best [ranged weapons](/wiki/Ranged_weapon "Ranged weapon"), offensive spells and/or [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand") where possible. Wands of [sleep](/wiki/Wand_of_sleep "Wand of sleep") and [slow monster](/wiki/Wand_of_slow_monster "Wand of slow monster") can work in a cautious fighter's favor and can also work as a means of escaping them, and wands of [magic missile](/wiki/Wand_of_magic_missile "Wand of magic missile") are also somewhat effective. Even if you can contain a group of soldier ants to a corridor, their damage and speed makes it wisest to bring them all down quickly as possible. Once killed, soldier ant corpses can be used as a source of poison resistance for characters who lack the intrinsic, but have an external source on hand and/or a [tinning kit](/wiki/Tinning_kit "Tinning kit") to make them safe to eat.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Poison no longer causes instadeath, but still results in significant damage to HP and attributes.

## History

The soldier ant first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"). In Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, which are based on [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"), and from [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0") to [NetHack 2.3e](/wiki/NetHack_2.3e "NetHack 2.3e"), the giant ant behaves much like the modern soldier ant does, attacking with a poisonous sting and leaving a poisonous corpse.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Ant](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant "wikipedia:Ant")***

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Army ant](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Army_ant "wikipedia:Army ant")***

Giant ants - specifically, ants or ant-like creatures that are human sized or larger - are a popular form of insectoid in science-fiction media, codified by the giant ants seen in *Them!* (1954) and *Empire of the Ants* (1977). Other notable examples include the Bugs of *Starship Troopers*, the Formics of *Ender's Game*, and the ants that accompany Marvel Comics super hero Ant-Man. Like other ants in various forms of fiction, they are commonly portrayed as a hive species, which is a common misconception regarding ant colonies.

The soldier ant is a nickname given to [army ants](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/army_ant "wikipedia:army ant"), which refers to any of over 200 ant species that display aggressive predatory behavior and travel in large foraging groups known as "raids". Unlike most ant species, army ants do not construct permanent nests, and an army ant colony moves almost incessantly over its lifespan. All army ant species are members of the true ant family Formicidae, but several groups of army anys have independently evolved the same basic behavioural and ecological syndrome: this is often referred to as "legionary behaviour". The largest genus of army ant is Neivamyrmex, which contains more than 120 species; the name comes from the common name for the most predominant species of army ant, *[Eciton burchellii](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eciton_burchellii "wikipedia:Eciton burchellii")*.

The soldier ant of *NetHack* is derived from the "warrior" giant ants *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, which have the same hit dice, armor class and damage dice. 'Warrior' ants make up roughly 1⁄10 of giant ants that a group will encounter, especially within their nests where there is one warrior for every 5 workers, and 5 warrior ants guard the egg chamber. If the queen ant is killed, the warriors will become confused for six rounds before fleeing the nest like the other ants.

## Variants

In variants that incorporate the [Convict](/wiki/Convict "Convict") patch, the soldier ant is the first [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") monster for Convicts, and makes up 96⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Convict quest](/wiki/Convict_quest "Convict quest").

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), soldier ants are lawful.

Several soldier ants are encountered on [the Lawful Quest](/wiki/Law_quest_\(dNethack\) "Law quest (dNethack)"), and [can generate with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") armor made to fit their body shape - this is a [pun](/wiki/Pun "Pun") on their nickname. A soldier ant generated on the Lawful Quest has a 3⁄5 chance of generating with armor: a 1⁄10 chance of generating with [plate mail](/wiki/Plate_mail "Plate mail"), a 1⁄5 chance of generating with [chain mail](/wiki/Chain_mail "Chain mail"), and a 3⁄10 chance of generating with [scale mail](/wiki/Scale_mail "Scale mail"); soldier ants that receive any body armor will also generate with a [helmet](/wiki/Helmet "Helmet").

## Encyclopedia entry

This giant variety of the ordinary ant will fight just as  
fiercely as its small, distant cousin. Various varieties  
exist, and they are known and feared for their relentless  
persecution of their victims.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 494](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkroom.c#L494)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/mcastu.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 589](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mcastu.c#L589)
